title: Two million switch bank accounts in two years
text:

Wed, Sep 16, 2015, 06:57 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 3 mins Two million switch bank accounts in two years By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 42 minutes ago 259.65 +5.15 
The seven-day current account switch service is two years old, but has not lived up to the expectations of some of those in the industry 
Two million bank customers have used the seven-day switching service to jump from on bank to a rival in the first two years of the service. 
The system was designed to make it easier to move bank, enhancing competition and giving unhappy customers a way to try out an alternative service . 
However, the 2m number falls well short of the 5m per year that some in the industry expected when the system was launched in 2013. 
With almost 50m current accounts open in the UK, the 2m figure indicates that just 2pc of customers are using the seven-day system each year. 
Even (Taiwan OTC: 6436.TWO - news ) before the scheme was announced, some years saw more than 1m people move bank, indicating the system has only had modest success in encouraging mobility in the market. 
“Increasing competition in banking so that customers get a better deal is at the heart of the Government’s long-term plan,” said Harriett Baldwin, economic secretary to the Treasury. 
“That’s why we challenged industry to make it easier for customers to switch accounts, and welcomed the launch of seven-day Current Account Switch Service in September 2013.” 
Nonetheless, the industry has tacitly acknowledged the failure of the scheme to create a truly dynamic market it is launching a new advertising drive this week to promote the switching scheme further, as revealed by The Telegraph last month . 
As well as making sure as many customers as possible are aware of the scheme, the banks also have another motive to show they are encouraging switching. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is investigating the personal current account market , and banks are keen to show that customers are aware that they are able to move easily if they wish. 
The CMA began looking at a probe in 2013, and began it in earnest last year. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is due to publish an interim report next month, along with notice of any likely remedies which it feels are needed to boost competition further an eventuality that the big banks would like to avoid. 
Among the big banks, the winners under the seven-day switching scheme so far have been Santander which offers relatively high rates of interest, plus cashback on spending and Halifax, which gives customers a joining bonus plus a monthly payment. 
Meanwhile, RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) and Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) have struggled to attract more customers through the scheme. However, they do note that the data on switching numbers do not cover those customers who sign up directly without closing their old account, for instance students setting up their first account, or customers who want to keep both open.
